channel.description: A cleaned-up version of the original gaming feed for insider-gaming_com

item.title: Biggest And Best Remakes & Remasters Coming in 2026
item.content:encoded:
Despite a plethora of new games coming in 2026, there’s always room for classics being reimagined. Fortunately, there are a few solid ones for fans to enjoy. From iconic series to up-and-comers, no matter what type of gamer you are, you’ll find a classic game to enjoy in a whole new way thanks to 2026’s biggest remakes and remasters.

Insider Gaming has selected a few of the many remakes and remasters coming out in 2026. While more may come in the new year, these are the ones that are sure to cause a splash upon release. With epic shooters, intricate RPGs, and loads of familiar faces, these are the remakes and remasters you should look forward to in 2026.

Yakuza Kiwami 3 + Dark Ties

The Yakuza series has grown in popularity exponentially in the past decade. Its Kiwami remakes did help show off the originals well, so, naturally, a remake of Yakuza 3 was in order. Yakuza Kiwami 3 returns fans to Kazuma Kiryu and the crime-laden streets of Kamurocho. Now, he finds himself in the midst of a turf war with his orphanage at the center of it. Fortunately, for those who played the original, a new story in the form of Dark Ties will be included. You’ll play as the antagonist, Mine, as he rises up the ranks and of his side of the story. The Kiwami remakes have been great ways to experience the epic saga of Kiryu, so new fans should keep an eye on it for sure.

Tales of Berseria Remastered

Celebrating its 30th anniversary, the ‘Tales of’ series has been delivering fun and frenetic action RPG gameplay with each entry. As part of the celebration, many past titles have been remastered, like Tales of Xillia and Tales of Graces f. Now, 2016’s Tales of Berseria is getting the remaster treatment. Acting as a prequel to Tales of Zestiria, Berseria follows Velvet Crowe as she exacts revenge on those who killed her family. With exciting action gameplay, interesting characters, and a dark narrative, the remastered classic brings new additions like accessibility features and all DLC content. If you’re looking for a great classic RPG to get into, Tales of Berseria Remastered will do the trick.

Tomb Raider: Legacy of Atlantis

Lara Croft is back and seemingly better in the remake of the legendary 1996 title, Tomb Raider. Nicknamed Legacy of Atlantis, the game brings players back to Lara’s original journey to find the Scion of Atlantis. With next-gen graphics and modernized controls, it looks to be the definitive way to experience the iconic title for both newcomers and longtime fans. You’ll now be able to backflip, shoot your twin pistols, and kill dinosaurs in 4K, and who doesn’t love that? Plus, it acts as the perfect way to celebrate its 30th anniversary, especially with the upcoming Tomb Raider: Catalyst in 2027.

Trails in the Sky 2nd Chapter

After the critical success of the first remake, Trails in the Sky 2nd Chapter is coming sooner than later. Following the events of 1st Chapter, the game centers around Estelle as she ventures to Liberl to find Joshua. With a mix of action-RPG combat and turn-based mechanics, its unique blend crafts an experience not seen in other JRPGs. Plus, with new and returning characters and updated graphics, Trails in the Sky 2nd Chapter is primed to be one of the biggest RPGs in 2026. Its Fall 2026 release also means those who haven’t played Trails in the Sky 1st Chapter have plenty of time to catch up.

Dragon Quest 7 Reimagined

A stylized remake of the 2000 classic, Dragon Quest 7 Reimagined takes the iconic RPG series in a new direction. Taking on a diorama look with 3D doll looks for its cast of characters, the game delivers the fun and whimsy of Dragon Quest. Following an unnamed hero, you’ll travel with a ragtag group of adventurers to distant islands to ward off evil. Sporting the signature turn-based combat and the late Akira Toriyama’s art design, the fresh take is one fans have already fallen in love with. New story content and many changes to the flow and additional classes make Dragon Quest 7 Reimagined the perfect RPG to get lost in.

Dynasty Warriors 3 Complete Edition Remastered

With the successful soft reboot, Dynasty Warriors: Origins under its belt, Koei Tecmo is remastering one of the earlier entries in the series: Dynasty Warriors 3. The game, which was released in 2001, is considered a favorite among fans and critics, as its excellent hack-and-slash gameplay and visuals were a treat. Taking place after Dynasty Warriors 2, players will play as over 40 officers during the Three Kingdoms era. Given the advancements made since its initial release, including Origins’ 1000 v 1 combat and Unreal Engine 5, it’ll feel like a whole new game. With the series growing in popularity, Dynasty Warriors 3 Complete Edition Remastered is a great way to dive in and have some sword-slashing fun.

Fatal Frame 2: Crimson Butterfly Remake

The 2000s were great for the horror genre, but one series made waves in Japan and later in the West: Fatal Frame. While new entries haven’t happened since 2014, a remake of the second title, 2003’s Fatal Frame 2: Crimson Butterfly, will suffice. Following twin sisters Mio and Mayu, the two become trapped in a ghost-infested, cursed town and are forced to recreate the ritual that summoned the hex. Using your Camera Obscura, you’ll solve puzzles, locate important items, and kill dangerous ghosts. Fatal Frame 2: Crimson Butterfly Remake will bring plenty of spooks and scares to satisfy even the bravest, and it should be a worthwhile addition to your library—if you’re brave enough!

Halo Campaign Evolved

The campaign of Halo Combat Evolved is getting its own game, fully remade. Halo Campaign Evolved is the original game’s single-player, now with better visuals and new story content. As Master Chief, you’ll take the fight to the Covenant and uncover the secrets of the Halo ring. With fine-tuned FPS gameplay and many modern-day adaptations, it makes for a wonderful 25th anniversary celebration. It looks to be a very promising return to Halo Combat Evolved and the game that started it all for Xbox.

Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time

Released in 2003, Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time rebooted the ‘platformer’ for a new generation. Now, the classic game is getting a next-gen remake thanks to Ubisoft Montreal. Following a nameless Prince, you’ll use the power of time manipulation to stop the evil Vizier from taking over the world. It’s been in development hell for quite some time, changing studios and such. However, a promised 2026 Prince of Persia Remake gives hope to the many fans: Perhaps the Prince’s famed journey will see the light of day again.

Steins;Gate Re:Boot

The original Steins:Gate took many by surprise in 2009 with its genre balance and spectacular twists and turns. Fortunately for fans of the game and acclaimed anime, the visual novel series is getting the remake treatment. Titled Steins;Gate Re:Boot, the remake will bring the classic back to life with updated graphics and new content for longtime fans. As scientist Rintaro Okabe, you and your group discover and develop a machine that can change the past with dire consequences. With branching narratives, there’s a lot of content that you’ll get to enjoy, whether a newcomer or a returning fan.

Which remake or remaster are you looking forward to the most in 2026? A big-time AAA revisit of Halo or Tomb Raider? Or are you going on a Dragon Quest first? Head to the Insider Gaming Discord Server and get involved with the conversation.

Check out more fun IG lists: 8 Major Co-Op Games Coming in 2026, the 7 Biggest Fortnite Features Needed in 2026, and the 9 Biggest Nintendo Switch & Switch 2 Games Coming in 2026.

item.title: Minecraft 26.1 Snapshot 2 Retextures Baby Mobs & More
item.content:encoded:
Mojang have unveiled the first Minecraft Snapshot of 2026, and it’s easily one of the most wholesome ones they’ve revealed yet. Multiple changes have been made to numerous baby mobs, and they’re bound to steal fans’ hearts.

The most notable change made in the Minecraft 26.1 Snapshot 2 is the retexturing of multiple baby mobs. These younger mobs will now better reflect their adult variant textures, and some of them will even make new baby sounds.

Another change that fans have long been calling for is the introduction of craftable Name Tags. No longer must they be found in chests or fished up by chance; instead, fans can now reliably craft them and name mobs to their heart’s desire—all it costs is one Paper and any Metal Nugget.

Check out the full patch notes for Minecraft 26.1 Snapshot 2 below, and leave your thoughts on the changes down in the comments, as well as in the official Insider Gaming Discord.

Minecraft 26.1 Snapshot 2 Full Patch Notes

Changes

  • Name Tags are now craftable and can be crafted with 1 Paper and 1 of any Metal Nugget
  • Zombie Horses no longer panic when hurt
  • Tweaked default JVM options
  • Added new baby sounds for Wolf, Cat and Pig
  • Revamped the visuals of several baby mobs
  • The programmer art rabbit textures have been removed following the re-modelling of the rabbit

Baby Mobs

  • Updated the models and textures of the following baby mobs:
    • Cow
    • Sheep
    • Pig
    • Cat
    • Ocelot
    • Mooshroom
    • Wolf
    • Chicken
      • Tweaked the bounding box to align with the new model
    • Rabbit
      • Both adult and baby Rabbits also received new animations
      • Tweaked the bounding box to align with the new model
  • Armor on baby Wolves and saddles on baby Pigs will no longer render

Default JVM Options

  • The game now allocates 4 GB of RAM by default (up from 2 GB)
  • Garbage collection has been changed from G1GC to ZGC for compatible devices

Technical Changes

  • The Data Pack version is now 96
  • The Resource Pack version is now 77

Data Pack Version 96

  • Wolf sound variants sound events in wolf_sound_variant has been moved into a new field adult_sounds and field baby_sounds was added

Entity Data

  • The current_explosion_impact_pos and current_impulse_context_reset_grace_time fields from Players have been added to all mobs and the Armor Stand
  • The ignore_fall_damage_from_current_explosion field on Players has been removed

Item Tags

  • Added #metal_nuggets – Copper, Iron and Gold Nuggets

Resource Pack Version 77

Entity Textures

  • Added new entity textures:
    • entity/cat/cat_all_black_baby.png
    • entity/cat/cat_black_baby.png
    • entity/cat/cat_british_shorthair_baby.png

    • entity.baby_pig.ambient
    • entity.baby_pig.hurt
    • entity.baby_pig.death
    • entity.baby_pig.step
  • Added new sound events for the Wolf:
    • entity.baby_wolf.ambient
    • entity.baby_wolf.growl
    • entity.baby_wolf.death
    • entity.baby_wolf.hurt
    • entity.baby_wolf.pant
    • entity.baby_wolf.whine
    • entity.baby_wolf.step

Fixed bugs in 26.1 Snapshot 2

  • MC-302734 – Zombie horses constantly move in and out of water and burn to death
  • MC-304361 – The heads of zombie nautiluses have a massive empty gap on the back
  • MC-304705 – The E value in entity_render_stats in the debug overlay doesn’t work
  • MC-304761 – Spears’ charge animation takes too long to rotate sideways for slower spears
  • MC-305040 – Nautili spawned as a result of a player breeding two other nautili can despawn
  • MC-305104 – The “Programmer Art” and “High Contrast” resource packs are listed as incompatible
  • MC-305121 – Some expert level mason trades no longer generate
  • MC-305130 – Farmers sell suspicious stews with 20 times the intended duration
  • MC-305131 – Duplicate trade entries in journeyman level shepherd trades
  • MC-305132 – Master level fletchers can now sell tipped arrows of thick, mundane, and awkward potions
  • MC-305164 – Armorers now buy diamonds at expert level instead of journeyman
  • MC-305175 – The Lunge enchantment now works at 6 hunger and above, instead of 7
  • MC-305279 – Expert cleric sells glowstone instead of ender pearl

For more Insider Gaming news, check out the claims that a Fallout: New Vegas Remake is on the way, as well as the rumours that a new Wolfenstein could be in the works.

item.title: PlayStation Reveals Hyperpop Collection For Controllers and Console Covers
item.content:encoded:
PlayStation has just revealed a new collection of Hyperpop DualSense controllers and PS5 console covers, featuring three colourways.

It is finally time for PlayStation players to add some new colours to their lives, and the three new designs really know how to stand out. It has been quite some time since we received a new collection of PS5 accessories, and a brand-new colourway after the Chroma and Metallic collections was long overdue.

PlayStation Hyperpop Collection Releases in March 2026

PlayStation’s Hyperpop Collection adds three new colourways to the DualSense controllers and PS5 console covers. These are Techno Red, Remix Green, and Rhythm Blue. All three colourways follow a similar aesthetic, starting with a glossy black and shifting into vivid neons of their respective colours. Check out the gallery below to see the Hyperpop Collection DualSense controllers and PS5 console covers:

The Hyperpop DualSense controllers have been priced at $84.99 USD/¥12,480/€84.99/£74.99, respectively, and the matching console covers can be purchased for $74.99 USD/¥11,480/€74.99/£64.99. The console covers are available in limited quantities and will only be released in select markets. Players can start pre-ordering the collection from January 16, 2026, at 10 AM Local Time, on direct.playstation.com and participating retailers. The Hyperpop collection will be released on March 12, 2026.

In other news, rumours about DualSense V3 featuring a removable battery have been debunked. Additionally, PlayStation was recently seen promoting a Resident Evil rip-off, “Ebola Village”. What are your thoughts on PlayStation’s new Hyperpop collection? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about ID Software seemingly returning to Quake. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.

item.title: ID Software Could Be Returning To Quake
item.content:encoded:
It seems that ID Software might be returning to one of the most famous franchises under its belt, Quake.

The Quake series is one of the most popular franchises in gaming, redefining how the industry approaches first-person shooters. However, it’s been a very long time since we saw a new Quake instalment, with the latest being Quake Champions, along with some enhanced versions of older titles, so it’s high time we received a new game.

ID Software Rumoured to Return to Quake or Hexen

A new report by Windows Central, which talks about Xbox’s plans in 2026, discusses the rumours about ID Software returning to Quake or Hexen, as Microsoft now owns all the rights to both franchises. There’s a chance that we could hear about these games at Bethesda’s Quakecon event; however, if it is a big reveal, then it might be featured during the Xbox Showcase. Regardless, players should take this information with a grain of salt, as it’s just a rumour.

As mentioned above, the last Quake game was Quake Champions, a free-to-play title that was released in 2022. However, the previous mainline Hexen game was Hexen 2, released in 1997. At the last QuakeCon, definitive versions of Heretic: Shadow of the Serpent Riders and Hexen: Beyond Heretic were released for PlayStation 4, PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S, Xbox One, PC, and Switch. However, we haven’t received a new mainline instalment in close to three decades.

In other news, Doom: The Dark Ages was the biggest launch in ID Software’s history. Additionally, read about Insider Gaming’s Year in Review story, which talks about Bethesda having to go back to the drawing board after Doom: The Dark Ages. What are your thoughts on the rumours about ID Software returning to Quake? Leave your thoughts down in the comments, and join the official Insider Gaming Discord server.

For more information from Insider Gaming, read about the next Xbox reportedly featuring “full bore Windows”. Don’t forget to sign up for our weekly newsletter.
